title: SHO energy - object-spring K and U when x may be A

content.question: An object of known mass oscillates horizontally on a spring of known spring constant in simple harmonic motion. At a particular instant the object’s kinetic energy <math alttext="K sub O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub></math> and the spring’s potential energy <math alttext="U sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></math> are determined and are both greater than zero, with <math alttext="U sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></math> greater than <math alttext="K sub O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub></math>. Could the object’s distance from equilibrium be equal to the amplitude of oscillation at this instant? What reasoning can be used to support the claim?

choices.label: Yes. The total mechanical energy of the object-spring system can be calculated by adding <math alttext="K sub O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="U sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></math>.
Yes. Most of the system’s total mechanical energy is in the form of potential energy, which is true whenever the object’s distance from equilibrium is a maximum.
No. The system still has kinetic energy that must be completely converted to potential energy when the object’s distance from equilibrium is a maximum.
No. When the kinetic energy is less than half of the system’s total mechanical energy, the object is approaching the equilibrium position.

content.answer: No. The system still has kinetic energy that must be completely converted to potential energy when the object’s distance from equilibrium is a maximum.
